author: By Christopher Hall
title: Caribbean Splurge: A Sailboat of Your Own (Well, Sort of)
description: What you need to know to charter a sailboat in the Caribbean, from costs and type of vessel to timing and itinerary.
content: Last April, Chris Kotchick, a Scranton, Pa., oral surgeon, and his family spent a week on a chartered catamaran in the calm, clear waters off the British Virgin Islands. A crew of two — part of the deal — ran the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sara Tavares, Portuguese Singer Who Prized Her African Roots, Dies at 45
description: She drew on rhythms from across the African diaspora and sang in Portuguese, English, Cape Verdean Criolo and Angolan slang.
content: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon. She was 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: yawp
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word yawp has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 25 in “‘Partnership’ Review: A Lost Tale of Ambition That Resonates” by Darryn King:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York Wants to Pay Landlords to Fix and Rent Single-Room Apartments
description: Officials once sought to eliminate the small apartments, where kitchens and other amenities are shared, but now they’re seen as a solution to a housing shortage.
content: New York State is planning to pay landlords who rent out single room occupancy units, commonly known as S.R.O.s, in an attempt to fight homelessness by slowing the decades-long decline in the number of small, cheap rental homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The U.K. Parliament’s Rwanda Vote, Explained
description: The British prime minister faced a test of his authority as he sought to protect his flagship immigration policy from threats within his divided party.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a crucial test of his authority on Tuesday, facing down at least for now a rebellion from the hard right of his party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Montague
title: A Referee Is Punched in the Face, and Turkish Soccer Feels the Blow
description: The postgame attack shocked a country used to heated atmospheres at soccer matches. The team president who threw the punch was arrested and later resigned his post.
content: The punch landed only seconds after the referee Halil Umut Meler blew his whistle to end Monday night’s game in Turkey’s top soccer league. The first kick, and then the second, came after that, as the referee lay on the grass, desperately trying to protect his head with both hands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Maine Gunman’s Brain May Have Been Damaged in the Army
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 12, 2023.
content: “You are vibrating the brain, the nerves, the connections. Any of those connections get screwed up, you got problems.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
title: Attack on Pakistani Security Post Near Afghanistan Kills 23 Soldiers
description: Tensions have been rising between Pakistan and Afghanistan, and violence in the border area has increased since Pakistan directed all undocumented foreigners to leave the country.
content: Twenty-three soldiers were killed in northwestern Pakistan on Tuesday when heavily armed militants attacked a security post in one of the deadliest assaults on the country’s security forces in recent years, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Kleeman
title: Provocative Sex Is Back at the Movies. But Are We Ready for It?
description: After an awkward MeToo hiatus, ‘May December’ and other films are showing​ intimacy in messy, complicated ​ways again.
content: In Todd Haynes’s newest film, “May December,” Joe Yoo (Charles Melton) is a 30-something man in a marriage with an unconventional back story. He met his wife, Gracie Atherton-Yoo (Julianne Moore), the summer after seventh grade — but she was 36 at the time. She went to prison, but they stayed together, and the two eventually married and had three children. The couple are being shadowed by a famous actress, Elizabeth Berry (Natalie Portman), who will be portraying Gracie in a movie about the first years of their relationship. As Elizabeth enmeshes herself in their world, Joe opens himself up to her, and one evening, after she invites him to her hotel room, Elizabeth initiates a tentative kiss. “You’re so young,” she says. “Believe me, you could start over.” The two have sex, and we watch Joe thrusting briefly from a bird’s-eye view — a position of surveillance rather than intimacy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Lydia Polgreen Interviews Pratap Mehta
description: The Dec. 12, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Lydia Polgreen, with Pratap Mehta. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: The Challengers Weighing a Run at San Francisco’s Mayor
description: Mayor London Breed has many critics in the city, but so far only a couple of opponents in her bid for re-election. That may change.
content: San Francisco voters say in poll after poll that they’re unhappy with the direction of their city and that they don’t like Mayor London Breed. They say they want better leadership to solve homelessness, property crime, fentanyl overdoses and the city’s other crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Microsoft Agrees to Remain Neutral in Union Campaigns
description: The pledge is unprecedented for Big Tech and makes it easier for roughly 100,000 workers to unionize.
content: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: British Museum Details Extent of Stolen and Damaged Items
description: Parts of some missing objects have probably been sold to scrap metal merchants, museum administrators say.
content: Four months after the British Museum fired a curator suspected of stealing gems, jewelry and semiprecious stones, the London institution on Tuesday released further information about the fate of the missing items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Governments Do More to Discourage People From Smoking and Vaping?
description: France has unveiled new restrictions that it hopes will produce the first “no-tobacco generation.” Should more places embrace such initiatives?
content: Is vaping a problem in your school or community? What about cigarettes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Eases Rules on Preserving Cremation Ashes
description: Families may keep a “minimal” part of the ashes in a place of significance to the deceased, but the remainder must be placed in a sacred place such as a cemetery.
content: The Vatican said on Tuesday that Catholic families may ask to preserve “a minimal part of the ashes” of a relative in a place of significance to the deceased, softening a previous mandate that ashes could be kept only in “sacred spaces” like cemeteries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: A Timeline of How the Israel-Hamas War Has Roiled College Campuses
description: Since Oct. 7, there have been dueling protests, calls for the ouster of school leaders and threats from angry donors.
content: Since Hamas’s surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7, and the start of a counteroffensive from Israel, colleges and universities across the United States have been struggling to handle the debate and protests over the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa, Maggie Astor and Shane Goldmacher
title: Nikki Haley Endorsed by Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire
description: Mr. Sununu is popular in the state, though former President Donald J. Trump continues to dominate the field.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire endorsed Nikki Haley for the Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event Tuesday evening, casting her as a fresh face for the party who could take on the elites in Washington and move the nation past the “nonsense and drama” of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Melissa Eddy
title: Why Volkswagen Is Building a Team of 3,000 Engineers in China
description: Volkswagen is shifting more operations to China, tapping the country’s electric vehicle capacity and building factories.
content: A bright orange robot, 10 feet tall, looms over Volkswagen’s new electric car assembly line in central China. It was imported from Germany. The factory’s other 1,074 robots were made in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Unapologetic ‘Auntie’ of Indigenous Data
description: The public health researcher Abigail Echo-Hawk is a leading voice in a movement to empower Indigenous people, wielding data as a tool for racial equity.
content: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Zelensky in Washington, and a Texas Abortion Case Ruling
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Loses Antitrust Court Battle With Makers of Fortnite Video Game
description: The case could reshape the rules of how other businesses can make money on the Android operating system.
content: A jury ruled on Monday that Google had violated antitrust laws to extract fees and limit competition from Epic Games and other developers on its Play mobile app store, in a case that could rewrite the rules on how thousands of businesses make money on Google’s smartphone operating system, Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Campus Speech Is Vexing
description: The Israel-Hamas war has highlighted a tension that university administrators haven’t fully acknowledged.
content: The Hamas-Israel war has caused so much turmoil on campuses partly because it has highlighted a tension that university administrators haven’t fully acknowledged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: A Year of ‘Unreal’ Fire and Warming in the Arctic
description: Observations from researchers and residents, published annually in a report by NOAA, reveal a region grappling with rapid change.
content: This summer was the Arctic’s warmest on record, as it was at lower latitudes. But above the Arctic Circle, temperatures are rising four times as fast as they are elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Lionel Dahmer, Who Agonized About Raising a Serial Killer, Dies at 87
description: The father of Jeffrey Dahmer, he wrote a memoir that one reviewer said sought to “peer not just into the soul of his son but into his own.”
content: Lionel Dahmer, the father of the serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer and the author of a haunting memoir about his son’s youth, died on Dec. 5 in Medina, Ohio. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to the latest from Hurray for the Riff Raff, Danny Brown, Wishy and more.
content: At long last, year-end list season is (mostly) behind us, and we can once again enjoy music without the burden of trying to rank it (and then arguing over those rankings). New albums have time and space to grow on us; new songs arrive without lofty expectations, and are free to pleasantly surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: What’s on the Menu When Your Cat Goes Out? Probably More Than You Think.
description: Free-ranging cats hunt or scavenge more than 2,000 species, some of them imperiled, according to a new study.
content: Everyone can agree on one thing: It’s not the cats’ fault they’re bad for wildlife. Cats are carnivores. Their talent for preying on rodents is a big reason their ancestors and ours started hanging around together in the first place. But then, people carried cats around the world, into ecosystems that weren’t equipped for such predators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘Kevin Hart & Chris Rock: Headliners Only’ Review: Sold-Out Laughs
description: This Netflix movie is aimed at comedy fans, even if they already know many of its stories.
content: “Kevin Hart & Chris Rock: Headliners Only,” a slick, self-mythologizing piece of Netflix content that follows the two comedians on the recent arena shows they teamed up on, is aimed at comedy fans — even if much of it will be familiar to them. The story of how Eddie Murphy spotted Rock at The Comic Strip (now Comic Strip Live) and offered him a job on the sequel to “Beverly Hills Cop” has been told many times. And any stand-up fan on social media knows that Hart presented a goat to Rock at the end of their recent show at Madison Square Garden (as well as whether or not Dave Chappelle would show up). That doesn’t mean there aren’t reasons to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Calls Hunter Biden ‘the Son Donald Trump Never Had’
description: Biden is accused of living extravagantly while evading taxes. Kimmel described his alleged spending as an “early 2000s Charlie Sheen-caliber performance.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Orr
title: A Poet of His Time, for Better and Worse
description: A new biography and a career-spanning collection of Anthony Hecht’s work show how fluent he was in his period’s style, and hint at the ways it might have restrained him.
content: To write about the poet Anthony Hecht in 2024 is to invite the question of why, in 2024, anyone is writing about the poet Anthony Hecht. His work is so wildly out of step with contemporary practice that it seems almost to come from another, possibly fictional timeline — one in which poets could recite long passages from “Lycidas” from memory and would, of their own free will, be photographed wearing bow ties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: I’m an Adult. Why am I Getting Acne?
description: Pimples can pop up at any age, experts say. But at-home treatments can help.
content: Q: I rarely got pimples when I was a teenager. Now, I get them all the time, and it’s embarrassing. Why am I getting acne as an adult?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Warns Israel It Is ‘Losing Support’ Over War
description: The president’s words exposed a widening rift between his administration and that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as casualties rise in Gaza.
content: President Biden told Israel’s leaders on Tuesday that they were losing international support for their war in Gaza, exposing a widening rift with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who rejected out of hand the American vision for a postwar resolution to the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Who Would Give This Guy Millions to Build His Own Utopia?
description: Dryden Brown wants Praxis to be a crypto-city for tech bros and tastemakers. Just don’t ask for details.
content: When he took the stage at a conference for “start-up societies” in Amsterdam in October, 27-year-old Dryden Brown cut a rumpled figure, moving stiffly in a gray hoodie with a T-shirt poking out at the bottom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Dream of Talking to Vincent van Gogh? A.I. Tries to Resurrect the Artist.
description: Can doppelgängers of the Dutch painter help museums generate new interest and income? A.I. Vincent fields our questions (and makes some mistakes).
content: Vincent van Gogh has been surprisingly busy for a dead man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Prisoners Sue Alabama, Calling Prison Labor System a ‘Form of Slavery’
description: The plaintiffs, who are all Black, contend that the state regularly denies incarcerated people parole so that they can be “leased” out to make money for government agencies and businesses.
content: A group of current and former prisoners sued Alabama on Tuesday, saying that the state’s system of prison labor is a “modern-day form of slavery” that forces them to work, often for little or no money, for the benefit of government agencies and private businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Original Café Boulud Moves South
description: Acadia brings Levantine food to a prime Midtown corner, Parcelle Wine Bar Omakase combines styles and more restaurant news.
content: What a difference a few blocks can make. The original Café Boulud, an Upper East Side neighborhood hangout and destination since 1998, has moved south about half a mile to an area where its customers are likely to be driven more by destination. It’s now installed in a somewhat grander setting near the Plaza Hotel and amid a coterie of other French restaurants. Still, those who know and love the restaurant will recognize the menu; it’s divided in quadrants addressing Le Voyage, La Saisons, Potager and La Tradition, with seasonal updates for each. Right now expect to be tempted by short ribs, crabmeat, mushrooms, sunchokes and desserts sparkling with citrus. The executive chef is Romain Paumier, who worked at the original Café Boulud and was the executive sous chef at Mr. Boulud’s flagship, Daniel. He’s the latest in a kitchen that, over the years, has been an incubator for names like Andrew Carmellini, Gavin Kaysen and Aaron Bludorn. Katalina Diaz, formerly the executive sous chef for pastry at Daniel, is the executive pastry chef. Of all his restaurants, this is the one to which Mr. Boulud is most deeply attached, given that his great-grandparents opened a Café Boulud 100 years ago near Lyon, France, his hometown. The new Café Boulud, designed by Jeffrey Beers, moves into the space that previously housed Vaucluse and before that Park Avenue Cafe, Périgord Park and Voisin. Now with pale gray walls that echo the color of the recently redone Daniel nearby, the new Café Boulud has artwork, traditional detailing, velvet and leather seating in deep teal blue and amber; the space beckons with airy comfort, as yet another reaffirmation that fine dining is sticking around. There are a number of other spaces, including a bar that will open in February, and a series of elegant salons opening in the spring that will be the New York headquarters for Maison Barnes, an international realty company based in Paris, and Mr. Boulud’s new partner. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Has Suffered Staggeringly High Losses, U.S. Report Says
description: The declassified intelligence assessment also found that Russia’s objective has been eroding Western support for Ukraine, the country it invaded.
content: The Russian push in eastern Ukraine this fall and winter was designed to sap Western support for Ukraine, according to a newly declassified American intelligence assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: What Shape Is This Cookie Cutter? No Guess Is Half-Baked.
description: The r/WhatIsMyCookieCutter subreddit was created to help bakers identify stray cookie cutters but has evolved into an outlet for running gags and whimsical artistic interpretations.
content: During last year’s holiday season, people started popping into a baking forum on Reddit with two million members to share a photo and ask a burning question: What on earth is this cookie cutter supposed to be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
title: Leader of Elite French University Offers to Step Aside, for Now
description: Mathias Vicherat, the director of Sciences Po, has exchanged accusations of domestic violence with his partner. The police are investigating.
content: The director of the elite French university Sciences Po said on Monday that he would temporarily step aside from his role after he was accused of domestic violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: He Wanted Bold Shots of Color in His Home. The Reason: He’s Colorblind.
description: Fire-engine red, cobalt blue and a futuristic vibe: There’s nothing indistinct or ambiguous about this Manhattan condominium.
content: When Simon Elkaim hired an architect to redesign his Manhattan apartment, he was clear about his thoughts on color: the bolder and more vibrant, the better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler and Vimal Patel
title: Harvard Clears Its President of ‘Research Misconduct’ After Plagiarism Charges
description: The university started an investigation after receiving accusations in October as its president, Claudine Gay, was being criticized for her response to antisemitism on campus.
content: The battle over the fate of Harvard’s president, Claudine Gay, took an unexpected turn this week, as accusations of plagiarism in her scholarly work surfaced, along with questions about how the university had handled them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Sign of Healing
description: Peter Gordon’s latest puzzle has its own etiquette.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Catie Edmondson, Karoun Demirjian and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Says Russia Is Celebrating U.S. Divisions Over Providing Aid to Ukraine
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine traveled to Washington to make a last-ditch appeal for more help to fight Russia. But Republicans said they wouldn’t act without a border deal.
content: President Biden warned on Tuesday that Russia was celebrating American division over providing aid to Ukraine, as President Volodymyr Zelensky hit a wall of resistance from congressional Republicans during a daylong lobbying blitz in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Two Men Hunted Eagles in Illegal ‘Killing Spree,’ U.S. Says
description: The men shot about 3,600 birds and were motivated by a hunger for money, federal prosecutors said.
content: Federal prosecutors in Montana have charged two men with illegally shooting about 3,600 birds, including bald and golden eagles, in a “killing spree” that fueled a black market for tail feathers and preyed on a symbol of the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Hasbro to Cut 1,100 Jobs as Weak Toy Sales Persist
description: The announcement that the toymaker was eliminating nearly 17 percent of its work force came during the critical holiday shopping season.
content: Hasbro, the toymaker behind popular brands like Peppa Pig, Transformers and Magic: The Gathering, said on Monday that it would eliminate roughly 1,110 jobs, or nearly 17 percent of its work force, as the company continued to grapple with weak sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Lost Raymond Chandler Work Is Found. It’s a Poem.
description: Chandler, best remembered for his hard-boiled detective novels, also wrote poetry. The poem, “Requiem,” was among papers his family donated to the University of Oxford in the 1980s.
content: He was famous for his cynical, hard-drinking gumshoe, Philip Marlowe, and lines like: “It was a blonde. A blonde to make a bishop kick a hole in a stained-glass window.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Three Months After Biden, It’s Xi’s Turn to Court Vietnam
description: The Chinese leader wants assurances that the strategically important country isn’t taking Washington’s side against Beijing, analysts say.
content: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, arrived in Vietnam on Tuesday for a relatively rare trip abroad, seeking to elevate ties with an important neighbor just three months after President Biden visited Hanoi on a similar mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Plans to Meet the Families of American Hostages Taken by Hamas
description: President Biden will hold his first in-person meeting with the families at the White House on Wednesday.
content: President Biden will meet at the White House on Wednesday with the families of Americans taken hostage by Hamas during the Oct. 7 attacks in Israel, his first face-to-face meeting with the relatives since the crisis began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: India Is Transforming. But Into What?
description: Pratap Bhanu Mehta discusses the signs of rising illiberalism in the world’s largest democracy.
content: India is known as a country of paradoxes, and a new one has recently emerged. At the same time that the country is poised to become a major global player — with a booming economy and a population that recently surpassed China’s — its democracy is showing signs of decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Aid to Ukraine by the Numbers
description: Here’s a look at the assistance the United States has provided for Ukraine’s defense and the political debate about whether more should be sent.
content: Since Russia’s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, the Biden administration has sent more than $75 billion in cash and equipment to the country for its defense. Most of the aid has gone to Ukraine’s military operations, keeping its government running and addressing its humanitarian needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: George Cohon, Who Brought Big Macs to Moscow, Dies at 86
description: He was chairman of McDonald’s in Canada and in Russia, where he opened the chain’s first restaurant in 1990, engaging in what he called “hamburger diplomacy.”
content: George A. Cohon, a Chicago-born entrepreneur who, by introducing the Big Mac — or the Bolshoi Mak — to Moscow in 1990, helped whet Russians’ appetite for capitalism, died on Nov. 24 at his home in Toronto. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caryn Ganz
title: Holidays a Drag? Every Year, Thanks to Jinkx and DeLa.
description: The “RuPaul’s Drag Race” alums Jinkx Monsoon and BenDeLaCreme put on a queer, clever and heartfelt Christmas show that keeps getting bigger.
content: It was half past 3 the day after the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree lighting, and a pair of America’s most famous drag queens strode up to the spruce’s formidable footprint, chatting about abundance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
title: Finland Partly Reopens Its Border With Russia
description: The Nordic country, which recently joined NATO, has accused Moscow of funneling migrants to their shared land border.
content: Finland said on Tuesday that it would reopen two border crossings with Russia, partly rolling back a decision to seal the countries’ land frontier after a dispute about increased numbers of migrants in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: In Washington, Zelensky Faces Republican Intransigence
description: Also, Biden and Netanyahu disagree over the war’s next steps. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, trudged across Washington today, making urgent pleas for quick approval of more aid for his country’s war against Russia. But in the meetings that mattered most — with Republican leaders whose allies hold the decisive votes — Zelensky’s pitch appeared to hit a brick wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: K-Pop in Uniform: All 7 BTS Members Are Doing Military Service
description: The last two members, Jimin and Jungkook, began their 18-month military duty in South Korea on Tuesday. Some fans say they should have been exempt.
content: Fans of the K-pop band BTS have known for years that a day would come when its seven members would all be doing mandatory service in the South Korean military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Top Court Clears Path for Democrats to Redraw House Map in New York
description: The ruling could allow Democrats to tilt anywhere from two to six G.O.P.-held seats leftward. Republicans vowed to challenge any gerrymandered map.
content: New York’s highest court ordered the state to redraw its congressional map on Tuesday, delivering a ruling that offers Democrats a new weapon to wrest control of the House from Republicans in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘Madwomen of the West’ Is Comedy as Comfort Food
description: In Sandra Tsing Loh’s zany play, the stage is star-studded but familiarity alone can’t sustain this story about a group of old college friends.
content: There comes a moment when a show tells you exactly who its audience is. In “Madwomen of the West,” a nostalgic new comedy by Sandra Tsing Loh with a cast of baby boomer screen stars, that moment is a singalong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 12, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 12, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about the approval of a gene-editing treatment for patients with sickle cell disease misstated the clinical trial in which the adult sickle cell center at the University of Alabama at Birmingham participated. It was the trial by Bluebird Bio, not Vertex Pharmaceuticals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Ephrat Livni
title: Israel Announces Discovery of Two Hostages’ Bodies in Gaza
description: The remains of Eden Zakaria, 27, and Master Sgt. Ziv Dado, 36, were repatriated to Israel, officials said.
content: Israeli military officials announced on Tuesday that they found the remains of two hostages captured in Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel and have repatriated the bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: After 60 Episodes, Peter Morgan Says Goodbye to ‘The Crown’
description: Morgan’s opulent Netflix show about the British royal family set new standards for prestige TV. With the final season ending, he’s amazed he’s pulled it off.
content: On a chilly day in December 2016, Peter Morgan stood on a London street, watching the filming of a scene from his new television series about the British royal family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Lynn Levy, Sophia Lanman and Pat McCusker
title: An Epic Soundtrack for Your Holiday Party
description: Caity Weaver’s 10-hour holiday music playlist guarantees an event to remember.
content: Caity Weaver loves holiday music. She also loves throwing parties. A few years ago, she set a goal: Create the ideal holiday music playlist for the ideal holiday party. Little did she know that it would become an obsession. Throughout the year, she collects new holiday music, and each December finds her spending hours refining her playlist — adding, subtracting and rearranging songs in pursuit of party soundtrack perfection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Zelensky Begins Aid Push in Washington, Casting Inaction as Win for Putin
description: The Ukrainian president plans to meet with President Biden and lawmakers on Tuesday as chances of an aid deal in Congress have become increasingly bleak.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine began his last-ditch pitch for additional U.S. aid for his country’s war effort after arriving in Washington on Monday by declaring that the true winner of the stalled negotiations in Congress is Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Urged on by Trump, House Republicans Embrace Biden Impeachment Inquiry
description: The House vote to authorize a formal investigation reflects a political shift among Republicans and the success of a push by G.O.P. allies of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: When the House votes on Wednesday to authorize an impeachment inquiry into President Biden, it will be the culmination of a slow but decisive political shift among Republicans — urged on by former President Donald J. Trump and his closest allies in Congress — from a place of resisting such an inquiry to fully embracing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: COP28 Comes at a ‘Moment of Both Hope and Peril’
description: For this year’s United Nations climate summit, the reporter David Gelles flew to the United Arab Emirates to discuss the world’s environmental future with industry leaders.
content: About 70,000 people arrived in the United Arab Emirates, one of the world’s largest oil producers, for this year’s United Nations climate summit, known as COP28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The Climate Summit Starts to Crack a Tough Nut: Emissions From Food
description: A road map to trim the climate footprint of food shows how hard it is to feed the world on a hotter planet.
content: It’s hard enough for world leaders to figure out the future of coal, oil and gas in a warming world. What about the future of bread and milk?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
title: Bill Ackman’s Campaign Against Harvard Followed Years of Resentment
description: The billionaire investor has mounted a high-profile battle against Harvard president Claudine Gay over antisemitism and threats to Jewish students on campus, but long-held personal grudges play a part, too.
content: In the two-month battle over the fate of Harvard’s president, the billionaire investor William A. Ackman has cast himself as a protector of Jewish students and the standard-bearer for people who believe colleges have fostered a hostile atmosphere for critics of liberal orthodoxy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: $700 Million Deal
description: Is any athlete worth that amount of money?
content: This weekend, the baseball player Shohei Ohtani announced that he had agreed to a record 10-year, $700 million contract to play for the Los Angeles Dodgers. It is the largest contract in the history of major North American team sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Zulu King’s Reign Is in Doubt After South Africa Court Ruling
description: King Misuzulu’s claim to the throne in a storied monarchy has been the subject of a bitter family feud. The drama has captivated a nation that is home to about 14 million Zulus.
content: A judge in South Africa has set aside the president’s recognition of the Zulu king, the latest twist in a vicious and long-running battle over who is the rightful leader of one of Africa’s most storied monarchies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: At Trump’s Fraud Trial, a Courtroom Artist With a Different View
description: As an art project, Isabelle Brourman joined the courtroom sketch artists at the Johnny Depp-Amber Heard trial and now the trial of the former president.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump’s eyes drifted shut as his former accountant testified during his civil fraud trial in New York State Supreme Court earlier this fall, no photographers captured the moment: Cameras were banned during the trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Not the Romance I’d Imagined’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Flannel, fireplace, falling snow and frosty windows. The chilly Vermont evening felt so romantic, yet I stood alone gazing up at the stars, struck by both the immensity of the sky and the realization that this was not the romance I’d imagined. He sat inside the warm log cabin, claiming “it’s too cold” to go out. A few years later, I have a new lover who shares my sense of wonder. “Will you go look at the stars with me?” I ask. Wrapping me in a warm hug, he replies, “Always.” We step out into the starry night, together. — Kate Pearce
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Do You Believe in Monetary Magic?
description: What currency reform has in common with arsenic and sheep.
content: Three weeks ago Argentina elected Javier Milei as its new president. Milei ran on a radical libertarian platform, whose most notable proposal called for eliminating Argentina’s currency, the peso, and replacing it with the U.S. dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Michael Bishop, Genre-Busting Writer Known for Science Fiction, Dies at 78
description: His early work took readers to the stars, but his later work ventured into noir mystery and the back roads of the American South.
content: Michael Bishop, an author who was best known for his award-winning science fiction but who ranged far beyond the genre, venturing into realism, noir mystery and even Southern Gothic, died on Nov. 13 in LaGrange, Ga. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Britain’s Friendliest Bear to Hit the Stage in ‘Paddington: The Musical’
description: The star of a long-running book series and two films will hit the stage in a show currently being developed in Britain, producers said.
content: Paddington, the well-traveled bear known for his floppy red hat and love for orange marmalade sandwiches, is taking on yet another venture in 2025: the theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Metropolitan Diary Fans, It’s Time to Vote for Your Favorite
description: Five of the best Diary items of the year are contending for readers’ top choice.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about your role in choosing the best Metropolitan Diary items of the year. We’ll also get details on the latest milestone in the rollout of recreational marijuana in New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Seattle Police Investigate Deliberate Hit-and-Runs on Same Night
description: The authorities shared cellphone and surveillance footage of drivers striking pedestrians on the same night in November, seeking to determine if the episodes were related.
content: The police in Seattle are investigating whether two episodes in which cars appeared to target random pedestrians on the same November night are connected, a spokesman said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Ye, Formerly Kanye West, Previews New Music With Ty Dolla Sign
description: For months, the rapper has teased “Vultures,” his first album since he made a string of antisemitic comments last year. He said the LP will be released Friday.
content: Kanye West, the contentious artist and provocateur now known as Ye, appeared onstage in Miami after midnight on Tuesday wearing a pointed black hood that resembled a Ku Klux Klan robe — and the 10-year-old artwork for his song “Black Skinhead” — as the musician previewed his first new album since a string of incendiary and antisemitic comments threatened to tank his career in music and fashion last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Protests Are an American Tradition. But Why at Restaurants?
description: A recent demonstration outside a Philadelphia falafel spot was just the latest in a history of boycotts and conflicts.
content: George Recine, a Boston advertising executive, knew exactly where to eat lunch last week during a business trip to Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle, Alyson Krueger and Martina Tuaty
title: Can Sukeban Make Female Wrestling Fashionable With Americans?
description: A unique form of Japanese wrestling that mixes fashion and theatrics has come to the United States.
content: At around 10:30 p.m. last Wednesday, in a downtown skate park under Interstate 95 in Miami, four wrestlers entered a ring: Bingo, Midnight Player, Rina Yamashita and Stray Cat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Google’s Antitrust Setback Could Remake the App Economy, and More
description: Epic Games’s victory over the search giant could let app developers keep more money, and marks a fresh blow against Big Tech.
content: Epic Games on Monday finally achieved one of its longstanding goals: weakening one of the two major companies behind the modern mobile app ecosystem. A jury found that Google violated antitrust laws by maintaining tight control of its app store, harming the Fortnite maker and other developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. General Assembly Votes for Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire, Countering U.S. Veto
description: About three-quarters of the body’s members voted in favor of the nonbinding resolution. The result underscored the isolation of Israel and the United States.
content: The U.N. General Assembly demanded an immediate cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war in an overwhelming vote on Tuesday that highlighted much of the world’s desire to bring the bloody conflict to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Donald Tusk, a Man of Eclectic Identities, Returns to Power in Poland
description: The opposition leader was endorsed by Parliament as the country’s next prime minister, unseating the right-wing Law and Justice party that had long denounced him as unfit to rule.
content: It was just minutes after Donald Tusk made his triumphant return as Poland’s leader that his archenemy stepped to the podium in Parliament to rain acid on his parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: As Egypt’s Presidential Election Closes, No Suspense Over Winner
description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is all but certain to come out on top after a three-day vote, with the war in Gaza turning the country’s focus from economic calamity to security.
content: There were four men on the ballot when Egyptians voted in this week’s presidential election, but with rare exception, only one of their faces gazed out from billboards, banners, buses and lampposts across Egypt: that of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Auden Schendler
title: What It Really Takes to Fix a Monstrosity Like Climate Change
description: The idea that free markets can solve societal problems and that climate change can be fixed without regulation is a ruse.
content: I live at the base of Basalt Mountain, an ancient volcano that tops out at nearly 11,000 feet in the Roaring Fork Valley of western Colorado. An eruption 10 million years ago contributed to the contours of the landscape. In the mornings I drink strong coffee from a U.S. Forest Service mug, and I look out the window at the light on the peaks, at the wild turkeys pecking in the yard, at the deer so tame that I could touch them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Her Son Was Promised a Special Education Class. He’s Still Waiting.
description: Mayor Eric Adams said all children who required preschool special education seats would have them. More than 1,000 such students lacked a placement last school year.
content: Taslima Amjad has called, emailed or visited government offices in New York City nearly every day for months, in search of help for her 3-year-old nonverbal son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Sunak Won a Key Vote. But the Battle Over His Rwanda Plan Is Not Over.
description: The British prime minister’s contentious proposal to send asylum seekers to the African country moved forward a step, but it still faces potential stumbling blocks before becoming law.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a major threat to his leadership on Tuesday, advancing his flagship immigration policy over the objections of hard-right factions in his Conservative Party. But the victory may prove fleeting as he faces several more hurdles to the plan, which would deport asylum seekers to Rwanda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: In ‘Translations,’ What’s Lost When Language Is Looted
description: An exquisite revival of Brian Friel’s 1980 play at the Irish Repertory Theater is the first of three there by the Irish author.
content: A drunken philosopher alights on what may be his pinnacle argument: That we are shaped not by the facts of history, but by our imagination of it. “We must never cease renewing those images,” he says, or we’ll stop living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: A Texas Case Shows That Abortion Ban Exemptions Are a Sham
description: Kate Cox’s predicament exposes the lie behind anti-abortion groups’ claims.
content: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is the Real Meaning of ‘Pro-Life’?
description: A discussion about the phrase’s ambiguous meaning among Republicans. Also: The Texas abortion ruling; speech on campus; the Electoral College; Trump and NATO.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Arlette Bashizi and Hannah Reyes Morales
title: How Africans Are Changing French — One Joke, Rap and Book at a Time
description: More than 60 percent of French speakers now live in Africa. Despite growing resentment at France, Africans are contributing to the evolution and spread of the French language.
content: French, by most estimates the world’s fifth most spoken language, is changing — perhaps not in the gilded hallways of the institution in Paris that publishes its official dictionary, but on a rooftop in Abidjan, the largest city in Ivory Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google’s Antitrust Loss to Epic Could Preview Its Legal Fate in 2024
description: A trio of antitrust cases on the docket threaten to reshape Google’s business and sap its profits.
content: Google’s loss was swift after a monthlong antitrust trial in a San Francisco federal court. A little more than three hours after a jury had begun deliberating on Monday, they returned with their verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Election Worker Defamed by Giuliani Recounts Emotional Toll
description: In federal court, Shaye Moss detailed how Rudolph Giuliani’s baseless claims that she had stolen votes from Donald Trump ignited threats and left her depressed and fearful.
content: On Dec. 4, 2020, Shaye Moss, at the time an election worker in Fulton County, Ga., was summoned to her supervisor’s office, where she thought she would be getting a promotion for her hard work on Election Day, after a month of positive feedback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Eric Schmitt
title: Houthi Militia Attacks Ship Near the Red Sea, Pentagon Says
description: The attack was the latest by the group on targets in the Red Sea and the broader region during more than two months of war between Israel and Hamas.
content: A commercial ship was hit and set on fire by an anti-ship cruise missile in the southern Red Sea, an attack U.S. officials say came from the Iranian-backed Houthi militia in Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five Fast Favorites From 2023
description: Weeknight wonders from our list of the year’s 50 most popular recipes: coconut saag, shrimp tacos and gochujang buttered noodles.
content: We’ve just published our list of the 50 most popular recipes of 2023 on New York Times Cooking, and I’d like to compliment you on your excellent taste. The tinto de verano! Dumpling tomato salad with chile crisp vinaigrette! Mochiko chicken! Cacio e pepe and white lasagna! And the banana pudding from Magnolia Bakery in New York, which I think far outshines its famous cupcakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: To Testify or Not to Testify in Congress? Your Job Could Hang in the Balance.
description: Columbia University’s president declined a congressional call to testify about her handling of antisemitism on campus — and dodged a firestorm that cost one of her colleagues her job.
content: When Minouche Shafik, the president of Columbia University, was asked to appear before Congress to testify about antisemitism on college campuses, she cited a scheduling conflict and said she could not attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Most Read Food Stories of 2023
description: Readers ate up lists on the best restaurants, turned to reliable weeknight recipes and gladly took advice on frozen pizzas and saving money at the grocery store.
content: Every year, as the calendar draws to a close, we marvel at how quickly it flew by. Was this really the year of coronation quiche? Yes. And it was also the summer of Barbenheimer, Beyoncé and Taylor Swift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Volker Schlecht, Alexander Lahl and Max Monch
title: As Frogs Disappear Worldwide, ‘There Is No Way to Stop That Killer’
description: Mysterious deaths have occurred all over the planet and followed a similar pattern. Why have so many species vanished? And what does it all have to do with us?
content: We met the ecologist Karen Lips in Washington, D.C. One morning, she picked us up from a Metro station and took us to Shenandoah National Park, keen to show us a species of salamander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Eshe Nelson
title: E.U. Moves to Tap Frozen Russian Assets to Help Ukraine
description: A plan to use interest earned on frozen Russian central bank assets could provide up to 15 billion euros for Ukraine, but faces hurdles before final approval.
content: Following months of political wrangling, the European Union on Tuesday officially began a lengthy process to deliver on its pledge to use money derived from frozen Russian central bank assets toward the reconstruction of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada, Katherine Miller and Vishakha Darbha
title: Two Opinion Writers on the Biggest Takeaways From Liz Cheney’s Memoir
description: Carlos Lozada and Katherine Miller on Jan. 6, Kevin McCarthy and political fear.
content: Former House Representative Liz Cheney’s recently published book, “Oath and Honor: A Memoir and a Warning,” discusses the attack on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, its aftermath and the repercussions for the United States and democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Republicans Hold the U.S.-Mexico Border as a Bargaining Chip for Ukraine Aid
description: Democrats and Republicans have accepted at this point that they will not secure Ukraine aid without a deal on border security — but negotiators are still at an impasse over what that bargain would look like.
content: Republicans in Congress have tied the fate of aid to Ukraine to their demands for stricter border policies to restrict migration at the U.S. border with Mexico, vastly complicating its chances of getting approved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kapil Komireddi
title: Biden’s New Friendship With Modi Is Already Under Threat
description: Accusations that an Indian official sought to kill a Sikh separatist in the U.S. expose the fragility of the relationship.
content: The indictment unsealed in New York on Nov. 29 accusing an unnamed Indian government official of plotting the assassination of a Sikh separatist in America raises many grave questions. Chief among them: Is the partnership between the United States and India in peril?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Huge Cyberattack Knocks Ukraine’s Largest Mobile Operator Offline
description: The interruption could pose real danger in a country where many rely on phone alerts to warn them of impending Russian bombardments.
content: Ukraine’s largest mobile operator said it had come under a powerful cyberattack on Tuesday morning that knocked out service to millions of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: ‘I Have No Future’: China’s Rebel Influencer Is Still Paying a Price
description: Li Ying used social media to help tell the world about last year’s protests. Now in exile, he has been threatened and lost his livelihood for his defiance.
content: In November 2022, Li Ying was a painter and art school graduate in Milan, living in a state of sadness, fear and despair. China’s strict pandemic policies had kept him from seeing his parents for three years, and he was unsure where his country was heading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man With No Ticket or Passport Flew From Copenhagen to Los Angeles, F.B.I. Says
description: The man, believed to be a Russian citizen, was charged with being a stowaway on an aircraft, federal prosecutors said.
content: How hard is it to jump on an international flight to the United States with no ticket and no passport?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Zara Removes Campaign After Critics Call It Insensitive to Israel-Hamas War
description: The ad campaign, which was called “The Jacket,” reminded some users of Palestinians in the rubble of Gaza. Zara said it shot the campaign before the war began.
content: Zara, the fast-fashion retailer, said on Tuesday that it had removed an ad campaign, after critics said the imagery brought to mind scenes from the Israel-Hamas War and called it insensitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Luke Vander Ploeg, Shannon Lin, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Fizzled. U.S. Funding May Be Next.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has arrived in Washington at a critical moment, both on the battlefield and on Capitol Hill.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, is making a rare trip to Washington this week, pleading his case for American military aid, something which has long been a lifeline for his country but is now increasingly in doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Judge Upholds Texas TikTok Ban on Government Devices
description: The Texas law was challenged by First Amendment lawyers who filed a suit on behalf of college professors who said that their work had been compromised when they lost access to the app.
content: A federal judge in Texas on Monday upheld a ban that prevented state employees from using TikTok, the Chinese-owned short-form video app, on government devices and networks, rejecting a challenge by lawyers who argued that the prohibition had violated the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Gas Prices Are Falling Fast, Helping Tame Inflation
description: Consumer sentiment has rebounded as gas prices slide. Oil prices continued to fall on Tuesday, a move that could portend an even bigger drop at the pump.
content: In the fight to bring down inflation, the falling price of gasoline stands out as a victory, even if Federal Reserve policy has little to do with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Anderson Cooper’s Newest Assignment: Grief (His Own)
description: How do you memorialize the people you loved and lost? Object by object, the CNN anchor is trying to figure it out.
content: It took Anderson Cooper more than a year after his mother’s death to begin clearing out her apartment. It was an emotionally draining task, one that he put off — something his mother may have anticipated, because she left him a road map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Fossil Fuel Fight Goes Into Overtime
description: Negotiators are working through the night to reach a deal.
content: It’s well past midnight in Dubai, and negotiations are still ongoing on the last day of the United Nations climate summit, known as COP28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Revisits His ‘Illusion of Suffering’ on Broadway
description: The “Appropriate” playwright has teamed up with the actors Sarah Paulson and Corey Stoll and the director Lila Neugebauer for the play’s Broadway debut. “Everybody onstage is a political statement,” he says.
content: As with so many family reunion plays, the squabbling Lafayette siblings in Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “Appropriate” dislodge their share of skeletons from the closets of their childhood home, a former plantation in southern Arkansas. But here those secrets, hovering over everything and everyone, may be actual skeletons, and worse. The increasingly unsettling revelations power what The New York Times’s Ben Brantley called a “very fine, subversively original new play” at its Off Broadway premiere in 2014 at the Signature Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Michael Corkery
title: Medical School Dean Is Chosen to Lead Penn as Interim President
description: Dr. Larry Jameson was selected after M. Elizabeth Magill resigned amid an uproar over her statements about campus antisemitism.
content: Dr. J. Larry Jameson, dean of the medical school at the University of Pennsylvania, was named the institution’s interim president on Tuesday, three days after his predecessor resigned amid an uproar over how elite colleges have handled antisemitism on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: She ‘Review Bombed’ Other Writers. Then Her Book Got Pulled.
description: Cait Corrain, a debut fantasy author, admitted to creating fake accounts on Goodreads to bolster her own book and tank the ratings of others.
content: A fantasy debut author who had a two-book deal with Random House on Tuesday admitted to creating fake accounts on the website Goodreads to sabotage other novelists by leaving negative reviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Eric Schmitt and Ismail Alfa
title: Errant Airstrikes by Nigeria’s Military Have Killed Worshipers, Herders and Refugees
description: The U.S.-backed Nigerian military has been killing civilians in airstrikes at an alarming pace, security analysts and human rights advocates say, with little accountability.
content: Last week in northern Nigeria, two drone strikes killed at least 85 people who had been out celebrating a Muslim holiday in a village. In June, dozens of herders and their cattle were hit from the sky, in the state next to the country’s capital. And in 2017, around 100 people were killed in an airstrike on a refugee camp in the country’s northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Rod Stewart, Looking to Spend More Time in Britain, Lists L.A. Mansion
description: The singer-songwriter is asking $80 million for the sprawling mansion designed by the architect Richard Landry. He paid $12 million for the lot in 1991.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: In Indigenous Communities, a Divided Reaction to ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
description: The filmmakers’ attention to detail draws praise, but the question of perspective and who gets to tell the story is also at issue.
content: After watching “Killers of the Flower Moon” at a July screening in Tulsa, Okla., Dana Bear emerged from the theater with a complicated mix of emotions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Holds Roughly Steady Ahead of Fed Meeting
description: Consumer prices rose 3.1 percent in the year through November, and a closely watched core index was roughly the same rate as the previous month.
content: Inflation data released on Tuesday showed that price increases remained moderate in November, the latest sign that inflation has cooled substantially from its June 2022 peak. That’s likely to keep the Federal Reserve on track to leave interest rates unchanged at its final meeting of the year, which takes place this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Republicans Sideline Zelensky With Border Demands, Imperiling Aid Package
description: The Ukrainian president delivered an urgent plea for more help for his country in its fight against Russia, only to be told by Republicans that his challenges were not their focus.
content: As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine stood at a lectern in the Capitol on Tuesday pleading with senators to quickly approve more aid for his country’s war against Russian invaders, Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, delivered a blunt message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy, Lauren Leatherby and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Israel’s Evacuation Decrees Leave Gazans Confused
description: Even Gazans who can get access to Israeli directions online say they sometimes make no sense, which could be a matter of life or death.
content: The WhatsApp group members had advantages many fellow Gazans lacked: working cellphones and a way to communicate with one another to avoid deadly Israeli strikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: The Best Cookbooks of 2023
description: A rigorously researched guide on Chinese cooking, a choose-your-own adventure for pasta lovers and more, as tested by New York Times Cooking and the Food desk.
content: Scroll on Instagram or TikTok for even 10 seconds, and you know that recipe inspiration is easier than ever to come by. Despite the fire hose of cooking videos available online, we still can’t resist the allure of the analog: cracking the spine of a new cookbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
title: Lawmakers Call for Raising Tariffs and Severing Economic Ties With China
description: A bipartisan report recommended stripping China of the low tariffs the United States granted it two decades ago, among other actions.
content: Bipartisan lawmakers on Tuesday called for severing more of America’s economic and financial ties with China, including revoking the low tariff rates that the United States granted Beijing after it joined the World Trade Organization more than two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Wu-Tang Clan Announces Las Vegas Residency
description: The first four concert dates will begin with Super Bowl weekend in February.
content: Wu-Tang Clan will begin a Las Vegas residency in February as the city hosts its first Super Bowl, the Grammy-nominated rap collective announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Reid
title: The Strangest Toy on Wish Lists This Year
description: It’s part Build-A-Bear and part Easy-Bake Oven.
content: Here’s a holiday recipe you probably haven’t made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Why Jack Smith Is Taking Trump’s Immunity Claim Straight to the Supreme Court
description: The special counsel has substantive and procedural reasons for wanting a quick ruling on whether Donald Trump can be prosecuted for his actions as president.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel who has brought two cases against former President Donald J. Trump, made a bold move this week designed to undercut one of Mr. Trump’s chief defenses against accusations of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing: Biden Says Israel Is Losing Support
description: Plus, Volodymyr Zelensky pleaded for more aid in Washington.
content: A divide between Israel and the U.S. burst into the open yesterday as President Biden warned that Israel was losing the world’s support over its war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Skirmishes between Israel and Hezbollah.
content: Israel warned that attacks by the Hezbollah militia along the border with Lebanon could not continue and would require a response. In a show of solidarity with Hamas, Hezbollah has launched repeated missile and drone attacks on army bases and other targets inside Israel, forcing the evacuation of civilians and prompting cross-border strikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: BAM Announces a Dance-Heavy Season
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s winter/spring season will feature programs by Mark Morris and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
content: A rock opera by the performance artist Taylor Mac, the New York premiere of a dance work by Mark Morris and a film retrospective of the actor Jeffrey Wright are among the offerings of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s upcoming season, the performing arts center announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Hunting Ghosts in the Sky and Finding What Makes Their Colors
description: Scientists captured new imagery of atmospheric phenomena that occur during some lightning storms, offering clues into how they form.
content: In June 2019, scientists in Spain went searching for ghosts haunting the skies above the Mediterranean Sea. These green-hued wisps, dancing above pink-red, extremely high-altitude lightning during thunderstorms, had been discovered only in May that year. What were they? The only way to know was to capture one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Zahara, Acclaimed South African Singer and Guitarist, Dies at 36
description: A self-taught musician who sang in English and Xhosa, she was a prominent figure in contemporary Afro-soul known for her heartfelt voice.
content: Zahara, the South African singer-songwriter whose soulful voice and heartfelt ballads earned her platinum-selling albums and multiple accolades in her country, died on Monday in a hospital in Johannesburg. She was 36.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. Seeks Repayment of $63.6 Million From Former Official
description: The official was fired after investing millions in U.N. funds in housing and energy projects that went badly. He is contesting the order.
content: The United Nations has ordered one of its former officials to repay $63.6 million personally, after he lost a vast amount of U.N. funds by entrusting them to a man he met at a party, according to court filings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ricardo Arjona, Prolific Latin Pop Star, Says He Will Stop Touring
description: The Guatemalan singer-songwriter, 59, said that his latest performance in Chile would be his last after struggling with back issues that made it difficult to stand and perform.
content: Ricardo Arjona, the Guatemalan singer and songwriter known for dozens of Latin pop ballads that became international hits over a career that spanned more than 30 years, said he would stop touring, citing back problems and an imminent surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Watch What People Do, Not What They Say About the Economy
description: Of crime waves and consumer confidence.
content: Have you heard that there’s a huge wave of organized shoplifting — coordinated theft by groups effectively looting stores — sweeping the United States? You probably have. A couple of years ago, Walgreens said that organized shoplifting was behind its decision to close several locations in San Francisco. In April, the National Retail Federation issued a dire report claiming that “organized retail crime” was responsible for almost half of the store merchandise that vanished in 2021. The putative shoplifting tsunami has been relentlessly hyped both by the usual suspects, such as Fox News, and by some politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Will Cut Planned Electric F-150 Production as Demand Slows
description: Ford and other automakers have had to readjust their electric vehicle production plans because sales have been weaker than they had expected.
content: Slower-than-expected growth in sales of electric vehicles has forced several automakers to scale back once-ambitious production plans. Ford Motor has become the latest company to join that pullback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 23 of the Best American Dishes of 2023
description: As we scouted restaurants around the country, these were some of our favorites this year.
content: Each year as we travel the country to scout out candidates for our many best-restaurant lists — whether the big national listing in the early fall or the new “best of” city lists we’ve begun rolling out — our reporters and editors eat hundreds of meals in dozens of states. Inevitably we come across that one dish that we almost wish we’d ordered two of, and wish we could find closer to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri, Patrick McGeehan and Liset Cruz
title: Bronx Collapse Renews Questions About Safety of Aging Housing Stock
description: It was not yet clear what caused the corner of the building to crumble. City officials and prosecutors in the Bronx said they were investigating the collapse.
content: Around 3 p.m. on Monday, Maria Vargas was in her daughter’s room on the third floor of their Bronx apartment building when cracks shot across the walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Santos Reaps Notoriety’s Rewards as Prospect of Prison Still Looms
description: A video star on Cameo since being expelled from Congress, George Santos has begun negotiating with prosecutors in hopes of avoiding trial on a 23-count indictment.
content: If there were any notion that George Santos’s expulsion from the House of Representatives might find him in a state of self-worn disgrace, the past several days would appear to prove otherwise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Daphné Anglès
title: To Lure FIFA, France Floats the Promise of a Tax-Free Home
description: A plan to persuade sports federations to move to the country could save them millions. Supporters and critics of the proposal say it is intended to tempt one governing body in particular.
content: Call it a friendship with extremely generous benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Dana Goldstein and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Harvard’s Board Unites Behind Its President, but Its Campus Remains Splintered
description: Harvard’s governing body said it stood firmly behind Claudine Gay as the university’s president, a stance both praised and condemned by students, faculty and alumni.
content: As universities across the country strained under pressure to take a public position on the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas, few were as tormented as Harvard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez, Neil MacFarquhar and Thomas Fuller
title: As Fighting Rages in Gaza, Israel Issues Warnings on Another Front
description: Top Israeli officials hinted at a powerful response to attacks by Hezbollah across the northern border with Lebanon, as to the south Israeli troops wage street battles against Hamas in Gaza.
content: Street-to-street combat raged in what Israel described as three Hamas strongholds in the Gaza Strip on Monday, as top Israeli officials warned that increased attacks on northern Israel by Hezbollah, from Lebanon, could prompt a powerful response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Venita Blackburn
title: I’ve Never Watched Anything as Transformative as ‘Sailor Moon’
description: The show is about friendship, yes, and also liberation that does not match the world’s expectations of femininity.
content: The first lesbian relationship I saw portrayed on-screen was in “Sailor Moon.” Uranus and Neptune were two characters who seemed undeniably in love. The show is Japanese anime, though, and I could only watch the English-dubbed version that called them “cousins.” The titular Sailor Moon and the other Sailor Scouts are celestial superheroes sent across time to protect Earth from nefarious forces. In the human world, they take on the appearance of ordinary girls, but can transform into their fighting selves via personal totems. Sailor Moon often has a compact mirror and shouts, “Moon Prism Power, Makeup!” before transforming during battle and declaring, “In the name of the moon, I’ll punish you!” Swoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: How Unconscious Bias in Health Care Puts Pregnant Black Women at Higher Risk
description: Many Black women report feeling ignored or dismissed by doctors. The consequences can be deadly for mothers and babies.
content: Shakima Tozay was 37 years old and six months pregnant when a nurse, checking the fetal heart rate of the baby boy she was carrying, referred to him as “a hoodlum.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: In a Land Full of Stars, Los Angeles Can’t Stop Talking About Ohtani
description: Baseball fans everywhere were hoping that the megastar Shohei Ohtani would choose their team in free agency. Los Angeles Dodgers fans won the sweepstakes.
content: On Monday, a flawless day for baseball in Los Angeles if it weren’t December, Sean Teng stood in the top deck of Dodger Stadium after a tour and nodded toward the Hollywood sign off in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Red States and Blue States Are Becoming Different Countries
description: If you want a sense of what the future could bring if either party wins full control of the federal government, all you have to do is look at the states.
content: It seems obvious to say, but if you want a real sense of the differences between America’s two major parties — and if you want a sense of what the future could bring if either party wins full control of the federal government next year — all you have to do is look at the states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder
title: Gaza After Nine Weeks of War
description: After Israel’s invasion and thousands of strikes, many neighborhoods lie in ruins. Videos, photos and satellite imagery show how much has been destroyed.
content: After Israel’s invasion and thousands of strikes, many neighborhoods lie in ruins. Videos, photos and satellite imagery show how much has been destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Harvard Board Statement
description: Claudine Gay will remain president at Harvard University. Read the board’s statement of support.
content: Claudine Gay will remain president at Harvard University. Read the board’s statement of support.

title: College Presidents Under Fire: Who’s In, Who’s Out?
description: The presidents of Harvard, M.I.T. and the University of Pennsylvania faced a firestorm after testimony to Congress.
content: The presidents of Harvard, M.I.T. and the University of Pennsylvania faced a firestorm after testimony to Congress.

title: What Is the Path to Peace in Gaza? Here Are 10 Ideas.
description: Ten visions of postwar scenarios for Gaza from politicians, academics, activists and analysts.

title: At Home With Anderson Cooper
description: How do you memorialize the people you loved and lost? Object by object, the CNN anchor is trying to figure it out.
content: How do you memorialize the people you loved and lost? Object by object, the CNN anchor is trying to figure it out.

title: An Adventurous Apartment in TriBeCa
description: Fire-engine red, cobalt blue and a futuristic vibe: There’s nothing indistinct or ambiguous about this Manhattan condominium.
content: Fire-engine red, cobalt blue and a futuristic vibe: There’s nothing indistinct or ambiguous about this Manhattan condominium.

author: By Volker Schlecht, Alexander Lahl and Max Monch
title: The Waiting
description: The ecologist Karen Lips observed frogs for several years in Central America. She left briefly, and when she returned, the frogs were gone. She sets out to find them and encounters a horrible truth.
content: The ecologist Karen Lips observed frogs for several years in Central America. She left briefly, and when she returned, the frogs were gone. She sets out to find them and encounters a horrible truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Chow
title: Tater Tots With Caviar
description: The chef Yann Nury makes his tater tots from scratch, frying them in duck fat for extra rich flavor.
content: The chef Yann Nury makes his tater tots from scratch, frying them in duck fat for extra rich flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso, Dahlia Kozlowsky and Axel Boada
title: Israeli Mother Describes Her 52 Days as a Hamas Hostage
description: Sharon Alony-Cunio and her twin 3-year-old daughters survived 52 days in Hamas captivity. Her husband is still being held in Gaza.
content: Sharon Alony-Cunio and her twin 3-year-old daughters survived 52 days in Hamas captivity. Her husband is still being held in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Putin ‘Banking On’ U.S. Failing to Deliver Aid to Ukraine, Biden Says
description: President Biden said he approved more aid for critical equipment for Ukraine.
content: President Biden said he approved more aid for critical equipment for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times
